articles.headline: Volkswagen Names Matthias Müller, an Insider, as Chief Executive
articles.snippet: The company’s chief, Martin Winterkorn, resigned this week in response to the scandal over emissions tests. Mr. Müller moves over from Porsche.
articles.abstract: The company’s chief, Martin Winterkorn, resigned this week in response to the scandal over emissions tests. Mr. Müller moves over from Porsche.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen on Friday tried to move beyond the emissions cheating scandal that has threatened to cripple it, naming Matthias Müller, the head of the company’s Porsche unit, as chief executive.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: John Boehner Successor Is Likely to Face Similar Problems
articles.snippet: Whoever takes over will be under pressure to confront Democrats and the White House more strongly, meaning the job probably won’t get any easier.
articles.abstract: Whoever takes over will be under pressure to confront Democrats and the White House more strongly, meaning the job probably won’t get any easier.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after Republicans swept to victory in November 2010, catapulting John A. Boehner to the speaker’s chair, he was asked how he could possibly persuade House conservatives to do some of the tough jobs of governing like raising the federal debt limit.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Investigate Claims That Google Used Android to Promote Its Products
articles.snippet: Some mobile application makers have complained to the Justice Department about a Google requirement that they take a bundle of its services if they want any one of them.
articles.abstract: Some mobile application makers have complained to the Justice Department about a Google requirement that they take a bundle of its services if they want any one of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s regulatory problems have stretched across the globe. Now, they are coming back home.

articles.headline: With Subscription Snacks, Entrepreneurs Think Inside the Box
articles.snippet: Subscription snack and food box businesses are popping up everywhere, hoping to cash in on America’s appetite for novelty, convenience and munchies.
articles.abstract: Subscription snack and food box businesses are popping up everywhere, hoping to cash in on America’s appetite for novelty, convenience and munchies.
articles.lead_paragraph: When promotions for two subscription snack box services, Naturebox and Graze, popped up in his Facebook feed, Matt Feit was interested.

articles.headline: Rhode Island Averts Pension Disaster Without Raising Taxes
articles.snippet: Gov. Gina M. Raimondo has finished a pension overhaul that reduces benefits, but does not raise taxes or issue risky pension-obligation bonds.
articles.abstract: Gov. Gina M. Raimondo has finished a pension overhaul that reduces benefits, but does not raise taxes or issue risky pension-obligation bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chicago is facing its biggest tax increase in memory, to raise money for pension payments. Illinois is stymied by a $110 billion pension shortfall. In New Jersey, public workers are in court over a failed pension deal. From Pennsylvania to California, pensions costs are crowding out aid for public education.

articles.headline: Refugee Crisis in Syria Raises Fears in South Carolina
articles.snippet: The possibility of a wave of refugees has divided the state’s northwest corner, where critics worry they will burden services and alter the character of communities.
articles.abstract: The possibility of a wave of refugees has divided the state’s northwest corner, where critics worry they will burden services and alter the character of communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNCAN, S.C. — The worried citizens gathered in the high school cafeteria, about 200 strong. Patriotic songs played on the stereo, a man in a blue blazer from the John Birch Society hovered by a well-stocked literature table, and Lauren L. Martel, a lawyer from Hilton Head, told the crowd that 25 Syrian refugees were already living among them.

articles.headline: Complex Car Software Becomes the Weak Spot Under the Hood
articles.snippet: For all the sophistication of modern cars, recent hacking episodes and the Volkswagen scandal show the risks that come with advances.
articles.abstract: For all the sophistication of modern cars, recent hacking episodes and the Volkswagen scandal show the risks that come with advances.
articles.byline: By David Gelles, Hiroko Tabuchi and Matthew Dolan

articles.headline: The Post-Boehner Congress and Washington’s Sense of Dread
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner’s resignation is likely to herald an even more combative stretch in Washington, emboldening conservatives to defy President Obama on spending, debt and taxes.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner’s resignation is likely to herald an even more combative stretch in Washington, emboldening conservatives to defy President Obama on spending, debt and taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the White House, a stunned President Obama expressed hope for bipartisan progress as turmoil among Republicans ended Representative John A. Boehner’s speakership.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Smaller, Faster, Cheaper, Over: The Future of Computer Chips
articles.snippet: Fifty years after Gordon Moore made the galvanizing prediction known as Moore’s Law, growth in computing power is slowing.
articles.abstract: Fifty years after Gordon Moore made the galvanizing prediction known as Moore’s Law, growth in computing power is slowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the inaugural International Solid-State Circuits Conference held on the campus of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia in 1960, a young computer engineer named Douglas Engelbart introduced the electronics industry to the remarkably simple but groundbreaking concept of “scaling.”

articles.headline: As Volkswagen Pushed to Be No. 1, Ambitions Fueled a Scandal
articles.snippet: Volkswagen’s unbridled ambition — aiming to triple sales in a decade and overtake top carmaker Toyota — is central to what is shaping up to be one of the great corporate scandals of the age.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen’s unbridled ambition — aiming to triple sales in a decade and overtake top carmaker Toyota — is central to what is shaping up to be one of the great corporate scandals of the age.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Winterkorn, Volkswagen’s chief executive, took the stage four years ago at the automaker’s new plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., and outlined a bold strategy. The company, he said, was in the midst of a plan to more than triple its sales in the United States in just a decade — setting it on a course to sweep by Toyota to become the world’s largest automaker.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Aaron M. Kessler and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: A Pastoral Pope, Slipping Conservatives’ Grasp
articles.snippet: Francis seemed to defy church conservatives on Saturday with broad and generous calls for tolerance and contemplation.
articles.abstract: Francis seemed to defy church conservatives on Saturday with broad and generous calls for tolerance and contemplation.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Cardinal Gerhard Ludwig Müller, the Vatican’s chief doctrinal watchdog, sat cross-legged in front of a large television on Friday and watched Pope Francis at the United Nations addressing a world that has warmed to the pontiff’s merciful message on issues like immigration, the poor and climate change.

articles.headline: Thousands Enter Syria to Join ISIS Despite Global Efforts
articles.snippet: Nearly 30,000 foreign recruits have now poured into Syria to join the civil war, stark evidence that an international effort to enforce antiterrorism laws is not diminishing the militants’ ranks.
articles.abstract: Nearly 30,000 foreign recruits have now poured into Syria to join the civil war, stark evidence that an international effort to enforce antiterrorism laws is not diminishing the militants’ ranks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 30,000 foreign recruits have now poured into Syria, many to join the Islamic State, a doubling of volunteers in just the past 12 months and stark evidence that an international effort to tighten borders, share intelligence and enforce antiterrorism laws is not diminishing the ranks of new militant fighters.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Money Flows With Refugees, and Life Jackets Fill the Shops
articles.snippet: A multimillion-dollar shadow economy has developed in Turkey to profit from the massive human tide rushing toward Europe.
articles.abstract: A multimillion-dollar shadow economy has developed in Turkey to profit from the massive human tide rushing toward Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — For months, Ahmed Abdul-Hamid, a Palestinian from the Syrian city of Aleppo, tried and failed to cross the sea to start a new life in Europe. The Turkish police detained him. Smugglers tricked him. Once, his boat stalled and he had to swim back to shore, leaving him stranded and broke.

articles.headline: India Replaces China as Next Big Frontier for U.S. Tech Companies
articles.snippet: With China’s president unwavering on tough Internet policies, Narendra Modi of India is sending a different message: Help India become an Internet powerhouse.
articles.abstract: With China’s president unwavering on tough Internet policies, Narendra Modi of India is sending a different message: Help India become an Internet powerhouse.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — American technology companies desperately want to win over people like Rakesh Padachuri and his family.

articles.headline: John Boehner’s Move Deepens a Republican Chasm
articles.snippet: In the wake of Speaker John A. Boehner’s announcement that he would resign, the party’s internal struggle will be played out in Congress and the presidential race.
articles.abstract: In the wake of Speaker John A. Boehner’s announcement that he would resign, the party’s internal struggle will be played out in Congress and the presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Far from quelling dissent in the Republican ranks, the resignation of Speaker John A. Boehner is intensifying the divide that has emboldened hard-right lawmakers and insurgent presidential candidates, leaving a party that prides itself on orderly process in uncharacteristic disarray.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Russia Surprises U.S. With Accord on Battling ISIS
articles.snippet: Russia left the United States scrambling by reaching an understanding with Iraq, Syria and Iran to share intelligence about the Islamic State militants.
articles.abstract: Russia left the United States scrambling by reaching an understanding with Iraq, Syria and Iran to share intelligence about the Islamic State militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — For the second time this month, Russia moved to expand its political and military influence in the Syria conflict and left the United States scrambling, this time by reaching an understanding, announced on Sunday, with Iraq, Syria and Iran to share intelligence about the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Lawyer, Gary Reback, Takes Antitrust Fight to Europe
articles.snippet: Gary Reback, who persuaded the federal government to bring a case against Microsoft in the 1990s, is now pursuing a case against Google.
articles.abstract: Gary Reback, who persuaded the federal government to bring a case against Microsoft in the 1990s, is now pursuing a case against Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In the 1990s, Gary Reback was known as Silicon Valley’s dragon slayer, a lawyer who persuaded the Justice Department to sue Microsoft, accusing it of abusing its dominant position in desktop computers. Newspapers and magazines called him an “instigator” who was “Bill Gates’s worst nightmare.”

articles.headline: VW’s Pitch to Americans Relied on Fun and Fantasy
articles.snippet: The disgraced German automaker’s commercials, long known for their humor, promised diesel cars that were fun, quiet, efficient and, critically, clean.
articles.abstract: The disgraced German automaker’s commercials, long known for their humor, promised diesel cars that were fun, quiet, efficient and, critically, clean.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s big push in the United States revolved around making Americans love driving a diesel car again — a challenging task given the poor image diesel had endured since the 1980s.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Brands Woo Millennials With a Wink, an Emoji or Whatever It Takes
articles.snippet: Marketers are resorting to emojis, outrageous stunts and elaborate events to reach a demographic that has little tolerance for traditional advertising.
articles.abstract: Marketers are resorting to emojis, outrageous stunts and elaborate events to reach a demographic that has little tolerance for traditional advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Perel spends at least an hour a day on his iPhone 6. He watches live sports on television and tries to catch “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS, but he rarely tunes in to prime-time shows. He does not have a Netflix subscription, but he is thinking hard about getting one.

articles.headline: Pope Departs, After Showing a Deft Touch
articles.snippet: Francis demonstrated a nuanced political dexterity, effectively sidestepping the familiar framework of American debate while charting his own broader path.
articles.abstract: Francis demonstrated a nuanced political dexterity, effectively sidestepping the familiar framework of American debate while charting his own broader path.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Six days ago, Pope Francis landed in Washington for his first visit to the United States — a country that he did not know and that did not know him. He flew out Sunday night, having wowed Washington and New York, while leaving behind a downtown Philadelphia transformed into a “Francisville” of pilgrims, families and hawkers selling Francis swag.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: In Quest for Global Presence, Netflix Acquires Rights to 3 More Shows
articles.snippet: The streaming service plans to announce licensing deals for the CW telenovela “Jane the Virgin,” the CBS thriller “Zoo” and the USA drama “Colony.”
articles.abstract: The streaming service plans to announce licensing deals for the CW telenovela “Jane the Virgin,” the CBS thriller “Zoo” and the USA drama “Colony.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix is trying to persuade TV companies that it’s a friend, not a foe.

articles.headline: Limited Progress Seen Even as More Nations Step Up on Climate
articles.snippet: The pledges to battle climate change would still allow the world to heat up to a level that is likely to produce catastrophes, scientists say.
articles.abstract: The pledges to battle climate change would still allow the world to heat up to a level that is likely to produce catastrophes, scientists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pledges that countries are making to battle climate change would still allow the world to heat up by more than 6 degrees Fahrenheit, a new analysis shows, a level that scientists say is likely to produce catastrophes ranging from food shortages to widespread extinctions of plant and animal life.
articles.byline: By Justin Gillis and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Shell Exits Arctic as Slump in Oil Prices Forces Industry to Retrench
articles.snippet: In one sign of the industrywide trend, Royal Dutch Shell has ended its expensive nine-year effort to explore for oil in the Alaskan Arctic.
articles.abstract: In one sign of the industrywide trend, Royal Dutch Shell has ended its expensive nine-year effort to explore for oil in the Alaskan Arctic.
articles.lead_paragraph: As oil prices have continued their steady decline this year, rig after rig has been shut down, costing thousands of jobs in the United States. Yet major oil producers have been loath to pull the plug on their most ambitious projects — the multibillion-dollar investments that form the backbone of their operations.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Migrants in Germany Fleeing Poverty Find Only a Ticket Home
articles.snippet: Berlin has put in place a system for sending home people who have come from poor but safe countries to seek jobs.
articles.abstract: Berlin has put in place a system for sending home people who have come from poor but safe countries to seek jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMBERG, Germany — When Hasani Kleart and 173 others were bused in from asylum homes across Bavaria, the first of about 1,500 migrants to move into newly converted army barracks, they had been full of excitement: freshly painted apartments, sprawling lawns, a state-of-the-art playground, even a basketball court.

articles.headline: Taliban Fighters Capture Kunduz City as Afghan Forces Retreat
articles.snippet: Insurgents conquered a major city in Afghanistan for the first time since 2001. Afghan officials vowed that there would be a counterattack.
articles.abstract: Insurgents conquered a major city in Afghanistan for the first time since 2001. Afghan officials vowed that there would be a counterattack.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of besieging the northern Afghan provincial capital of Kunduz, Taliban fighters took over the city on Monday just hours after advancing, officials said, as government security forces fully retreated to the city’s outlying airport.
articles.byline: By Joseph Goldstein and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: Momentum Grows for Jack Dorsey to Be Twitter’s Permanent C.E.O.
articles.snippet: There has been concern that he would be too distracted by Square, the payments company where he is chief executive, but some investors say he is the right man for the job — both of them.
articles.abstract: There has been concern that he would be too distracted by Square, the payments company where he is chief executive, but some investors say he is the right man for the job — both of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Jobs simultaneously led two companies, Apple and Pixar, as chief executive. Elon Musk is running Tesla and SpaceX. Now more people are saying that Jack Dorsey can permanently run two companies at the same time, too.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel
